newsitem.title: CHINA: Police smash two kidnap rings in southern China.
newsitem.headline: Police smash two kidnap rings in southern China.

text.p: Police in southern China have smashed two gangs trafficking in women and children, arresting a total of 33 suspects and rescuing 17 boys and seven women, state media said on Tuesday.
Police arrested 27 people for kidnapping 31 boys around Liuzhou city in the southern province of Guangxi over the past two years, the China Business Times said.

The kidnappers tempted the children with food and toys and sold them for up to 12,000 yuan ($1,440) each in the neighbouring and wealthier province of Guangdong where families pay high sums for a coveted son.
Authorities returned 17 of the children, aged between three and 12, to Liuzhou last week where most were reunited with their families, the newspaper said.
Four of the boys -- kidnapped for between four months and two years -- had not yet been claimed by their relatives.
Police were still searching for 14 boys, it said.
Police arrested six men in the southern coastal town of Shantou last month for kidnapping and selling 16 women and rescuing seven of their victims, the China news service said.
The women, who came from other provinces to work in the coastal boomtown, were lured by offers to go out singing or for a late night snack, it said.
It gave no details of the nine women still missing.

China has long fought to end trafficking in women and children, but the ancient trade continues in many rural areas, fuelled by a shortage of eligible women and the strong desire among many farmers for a son.
The trade in children is exacerbated by China's strict one couple, one child family planning policy that is raising the ratio of men to women.
Rural families have been known to abort or kill female offspring to make sure they have a son.
